shared.footerContent:
If you’re interested in working together, get in touch.

[hi@emmacormick.com](mailto:hi@emmacormick.com)

home.name: Emma Cormick
home.intro: I’ve recently graduated from Billy Blue College of Design, and am based in Sydney, Australia. I'm currently looking for opportunities with a company who loves designing amazing homes.
home.bioTitle: I aim to create thoughtful spaces designed for living.
home.bio:
I’m passionate about designing residential interiors which are personal, considered and thoughtful, both in concept and in detail. I believe everyone deserves a well-designed space of their own, so I aim for all my work to be affordable, and sustainable where possible.

My goal is to understand people’s unique and individual needs, and help them create beautiful, functional spaces in which they can live well.

the-gardens.name: The Gardens
the-gardens.type: Conceptual design / Spatial planning / 3D Visualisation / Drafting / Branding, Graphic & Print Design
the-gardens.snippet: A new development with 1, 2, & 3 bedroom apartments, designed with beautiful materials, natural light, decor flexibility, outdoor space, and a sense of community

pageBlocks.title: The Gardens
pageBlocks.content: A new development with 1, 2, & 3 bedroom apartments, designed with beautiful materials, natural light, decor flexibility, outdoor space, and a sense of community
pageBlocks.aside:
377 Darling Street 
 Balmain NSW 2000 

 1, 2 & 3 Bedroom 
 1 & 2 Bathroom

pageBlocks.title: A shared outdoors
pageBlocks.content: The Gardens complex is designed around a central shared garden space and private balconies, ensuring all occupants have usable outdoor areas. The garden itself is terraced into multiple levels to create a versatile mixed use space, and afford residents a sense privacy.

pageBlocks.title: Natural air and light
pageBlocks.content: The central garden corridor ensures that all apartments have at least 3 walls exposed to natural light, with large windows maximising air flow and natural light penetration.

pageBlocks.title: 5 unique styles
pageBlocks.content: The complex contains 5 unique apartment layouts, from 1 to 3 bedrooms, in order to accommodate a mix of residents and lifestyles. Larger apartments have ensuites in addition to the main bathroom, and all apartments contain an internal laundry.

images.caption: Fig. 4.1 – One Bedroom (also available in mirrored variant)

pageBlocks.title: Efficient, flexible, comfortable.
pageBlocks.content: All apartments are designed to be space efficient, but still comfortable. Custom joinery and sliding doors throughout maximise usable indoor space, while flexible layouts can adapt to a wide range of lifestyles.

images.caption: Fig. 5.0 – 'Bedhead' Custom joinery removes side tables to free up floor space

pageBlocks.title: Working around constraints
pageBlocks.content: The Gardens complex is a renovation of an existing structure. To avoid any major modifications, the new plans are built around the current positions of lifts, fire stairs, support pillars, and service voids.

images.caption: Fig. 6.0 – Plan showing new design worked around existing/unmoveable structures.

pageBlocks.title: Natural and timeless
pageBlocks.content: Apartments are finished with subdued natural textures, and are designed not to dictate a particular furnishing style, or taste. This ensures apartments can adapt to the occupant's personal tastes, and allows them to remain timeless, and flexible.

images.caption: Fig. 8.0 – The gardens promotional booklet. Including logo & branding

horizon-apartment.name: Horizon Apartment
horizon-apartment.snippet: Renovation of a north facing Darlinghurst apartment, designed to improve natural light penetration and flow of space.
horizon-apartment.annotations:
**Image Ref Sources:** 

 1. White Paint: http://bit.ly/2jnrRh0 
 2.  Timber: http://bit.ly/2yVyxdb 
 3. Stone: http://bit.ly/2hwY5WH

pageBlocks.title: Horizon Apartment
pageBlocks.content: Renovation of a north facing Darlinghurst apartment, designed to improve natural light penetration and flow of space.
pageBlocks.aside:
184 Forbes St 
 Darlinghurst NSW 2000 

 2 Bedroom 
 1 Bathroom

pageBlocks.title: Bright and open spaces
pageBlocks.content: The open space through the living, kitchen, and dining areas, allows natural light further into the apartment, illuminating the central corridor, creating a brighter, and more open environment.

images.caption: Fig. 2.0 – Model view, top down - Open plan allows natural light to penetrate further
Fig. 2.1 – Model View, Perspective - Open plan allows natural light to penetrate further

pageBlocks.title: Naturally lit living areas
pageBlocks.content: Functional rooms with less need of light are relegated to the rear of the apartment, allowing living spaces to take full advantage of the large, north-facing windows.

pageBlocks.title: A grounded, natural flow
pageBlocks.content: The central hallway also provides a natural flow to the home, grounding the space, and allowing residents to easily traverse the apartment.

images.caption: Fig. 4.0 – NEW - A more natural flow

pageBlocks.title: An easy renovation
pageBlocks.content: To ease the renovation process, the new design maintains the original position of all structural walls, as well as existing plumbing and gas infrastructure.

pageBlocks.title: Natural, light materials
pageBlocks.content: Walls are finished with low sheen eggshell white, allowing light to bounce and permiate the space, while stone and timber add a natural warmth.

potts-point-apartment.name: Potts Point Apartment
potts-point-apartment.snippet: Renovated single bedroom apartment in Potts Point, designed to improve layout and light, while working with existing bulkheads.

pageBlocks.title: Potts Point Apartment
pageBlocks.content: Renovated single bedroom apartment in Potts Point, designed to improve layout and light, while working with existing bulkheads.
pageBlocks.aside:
2/123 Some St 
 Potts Point, NSW, 2000 

 1 Bedroom 
 1 Bathroom

pageBlocks.title: Adaptive spaces for maximum utility
pageBlocks.content: The residence is designed to adapt to the needs of its occupants – spaces can be sectioned off as needed. The bedroom avoids built-ins to allow for a number of potential furniture layouts, increasing the flexibility of the space.

pageBlocks.title: Making the most of a small space
pageBlocks.content: Sliding cavity doors, as well as custom joinery, and built in storage maximise the usable floor space.

images.caption: Fig. 3.0 – Sliding cavity doors maximise usable space

pageBlocks.title: Maximizing natural light
pageBlocks.content: The layout takes advantage of the natural aspect of the building, maximising the natural light available for the living and bedroom areas, while the laundry & storage are positioned further back, ensuring no window light is wasted.

images.caption: Fig. 4.0 – Position of habitable rooms in relation to windows vs laundry/storage

pageBlocks.title: Keeping the original character
pageBlocks.content: The original flooring & bulkheads have been left intact, both to channel the original character of the building, and to ease the renovation process. Walls and joinery have been designed to work either under, inline, with or flush to the existing bulkheads.

images.caption: Fig. 5.3 – Renovated wall position vs bulkheads

cubby-house.name: Cubby House
cubby-house.snippet: A compact, affordable, and eco-friendly dwelling, designed in response to the growing housing affordability crisis.
cubby-house.annotations:
**Image References** 
 1. Porterspaints.com. Naturals - Milk Paint. Publish date unknown. http://www.porterspaints.com/paints/naturals/milk-paint/ 
 2.  Kirei.com. Coco Tiles. Publish date unknown. http://kireiusa.com/kirei-coco-tiles/ 
 3.  Kirei.com. Kirei Board. Publish date unknown http://kireiusa.com/kirei-board/ 
 4. Kirei.com. Kirei Board. Publish date unknown http://kireiusa.com/kirei-board 
 5.  Sudo, R. NUNO - Green Fabric. Published 2001. http://www.nuno.com/en/textile/green-fabric 
 6. Envirotextiles. 100% Hemp Textiles. Published 2010. https://envirotextile.com/hemp-fabrics/hemp-canvas 
 7.  Kirei.com. Kirei Board. Publish date unknown. http://kireiusa.com/kirei-board

pageBlocks.title: Cubby House
pageBlocks.content: A compact, affordable, and eco-friendly dwelling, designed in response to the growing housing affordability crisis.

pageBlocks.title: Compact but comfortable
pageBlocks.content: Designed to fit into a backyard, the compact layout maximises usable space, while minimising the building's overall footprint - allowing for a comfortable living space for two residents in a small home.

pageBlocks.title: Making the most of a tiny space
pageBlocks.content: Joinery designed specifically for the structure increases the versatility of the space, allowing the same rooms to suit different needs as the residents require.

images.caption: Fig. 3.1 – Bar table can extend into outdoor/entertainment area
Fig. 3.2 – Custom pull out cupboard keeps laundry compact and tidy

pageBlocks.title: Passive heating & cooling
pageBlocks.content: The house utilises its aspect, along with the natural flow of air to cool during warmer months (via passive cooling), while remaining warm during winters.

images.caption: Fig. 4.0 – Passive heating & cooling airflow diagram, showing heat escape via pop up roof

pageBlocks.title: Eco-friendly materials
pageBlocks.content: Materials were specifically selected to minimise both the cost of construction, as well as the ecological footprint of the structure.

images.caption: Fig. 5.0 – Milk Paint, Oyster White Wall Finish (Ref #1)
Fig. 5.2 – Kirei Floor Boards  General Flooring/ Ceiling (Ref #3)

pageBlocks.title: Southern Cross Aged Care
pageBlocks.content:
Schedule for an aged care facility, designed to create a beautiful, home-like space for residents, without sacrificing utility or safety. 
 
 View the full schedule here: http://bit.ly/2B0zst2

pageBlocks.caption: Fig. 1.0 – Southern Cross Aged Care Schedule

pageBlocks.title: Inspired by Australia's unique colors
pageBlocks.content: The palettes were derived from the colours of Australian eucalyptus trees, to create colourful, yet natural, and inviting spaces.

pageBlocks.title: Useful, not utilitarian
pageBlocks.content: Colours and materials were selected to maximise visibility and contrast, improving the utility of the environment for residents with aging vision, without resorting to garish, utilitarian schemes.

pageBlocks.title: Colour for wayfinding
pageBlocks.content: Colour is also used throughout the facility as a wayfinding mechanism, allowing residents to clearly differentiate areas and orient themselves accordingly, based on the wall, floor, and furniture colour of the space.

images.caption: Fig. 3.1 – Areas seperated by floor material/colour

pageBlocks.title: Safe, hardy, and easy to maintain
pageBlocks.content: Materials and furnishings were chosen for robustness, safety, and ease of maintenance in mind - with hard-wearing/high-grip flooring, easily washable paints, and waterproof upholstery throughout - all while maintaining a welcoming residential aesthetic.

images.caption: Fig. 7.0 – Florbo SureStep high grip vinyl flooring
